answers.answer: Diabetes has long been considered a contributing factor to afib. So I would guess that there must be a correlation between blood glucose levels and afib.If you google 'diabetes related atrial fibrillation' you will find many links talking about the association. Here's a link of a German animal study:http://www.apria.com/resources/1,2725,494-672236,00.htmlThis study concluded that Diabetes-related atrial fibrillation is associated with a remodeling of atrium characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis.

question: I would like to know if diet non-compliance in a diabetic can trigger episodes of A-Fib?  My mother was diagnosed 2 years ago with A-Fib after contracting Influenza A.  She has Type 2 Diabetes.  She recently has been eating a lot of things she shouldn't and last night was rushed to the ER because she thought she was having an MI, but it was her A-Fib.  She has a positive history for HTN, Smoking, and Obesity.  She also comsumes many cups of coffee/day.  I believe she may also have some sleep apnea, but I am not sure.  She certainly snores loudly.  I realize that all of these things can trigger episodes of A-Fib, but I am curious if there is a correlation between blood glucose levels and A-Fib.I am an RN and have exhausted myself trying to discuss all of the possible problems associated with non-compliance with her.  I think she believes because she isn't on dialysis and has all of her limbs she is doing alright.  I would love to know if her failure to comply with the diabetic diet could be contributing to the A-Fib episodes.  Thanks.
title: A-Fib
